nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by centering research design and formalizing causal interpretation of natural experiments and IV methods
Design-based empirical approach: identifying the source of treatment variation and constructing plausible comparison groups improves internal credibility of causal claims in nonexperimental settings

Imbens and Angrist formalized IV in a potential outcomes framework and proved the local average treatment effect (LATE) theorem clarifying that IV estimates identify average effects for compliers under random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance
Natural experiments and researcher-collected microdata became central empirical tools (surveys, administrative linkages, field experiments) for implementing design-based causal inference
Selection bias is the core empirical challenge motivating the design-based approach; LaLonde showed nonexperimental methods often failed to replicate randomized experiment results

Difference-in-differences and carefully constructed control groups (as in Card's Mariel and NJ minimum wage studies) operationalize the design-based approach to isolate treatment effects from confounders
Regression discontinuity, fuzzy RD, shift-share IVs, and randomized assignment mechanisms extend design-based identification to diverse institutional settings
LATE implication: IV estimates identify the average treatment effect for compliers only, highlighting internal validity yet raising external validity concerns when instruments induce narrow variation
The LATE framework separates statistical assumptions (random assignment) from substantive economic assumptions (exclusion, monotonicity), enabling targeted diagnostics and sensitivity analysis
Extensions of the potential outcomes and LATE ideas link IV, RD, regression kink, and simultaneous-equation estimation, clarifying what estimands represent under heterogeneity
Card's empirical work used natural experiments to produce surprising, influential findings on immigration, minimum wages, and schooling that challenged prevailing theoretical views
Card (1990) Mariel boatlift study: using a multi-city comparison, the large 1980 Miami immigrant inflow produced little effect on native wages and employment for low-skilled workers

Card and Krueger (1994) New Jersey minimum wage study: a custom fast-food employer survey and diﬀerence-in-diﬀerences comparison with Pennsylvania found no evidence that the minimum wage reduced employment

These empirical findings stimulated research on mechanisms and heterogeneity such as monopsony, skill complementarities, and local adjustment channels, showing design-based estimates must be contextualized for generalization

IV applications by Angrist and colleagues exploited narrow quasi-random variation: quarter-of-birth IV suggests about 0.1 year schooling difference and IV returns of roughly 10% per year; draft-lottery IV finds military service caused a roughly 15% lifetime earnings penalty for compliers

Conclusion: together the laureates advanced a practical, transparent toolkit—design emphasis, natural experiments, potential outcomes IV—that improved internal validity of causal claims and guided work on external validity and structural generalization
